qas.question: What division of the Quran is used for a month-long reading?
How many ajzā cover the entire Quran?
How many ahzab are in a juz'?
What is the term for a subdivision of a hizb?
What division is used for a week-long recital of the Quran?
What division of the Quran is unused for a month-long reading?
How many ajzā cover the partial Quran?
How many ahzab aren't in a juz'?
What isn't the term for a subdivision of a hizb?
What division is unused for a week-long recital of the Quran?

context: In addition to and independent of the division into suras, there are various ways of dividing the Quran into parts of approximately equal length for convenience in reading. The <a1_0><b6_0>30<b6_0/><a1_0/> <a0_0><b5_0>juz'<b5_0/><a0_0/> (plural ajzāʼ) can be used to read through the entire Quran in a month. Some of these parts are known by names—which are the first few words by which the juzʼ starts. A juz' is sometimes further divided into <a2_0><b7_0>two<b7_0/><a2_0/> ḥizb (plural aḥzāb), and each hizb subdivided into four <a3_0><b8_0>rubʻ al-ahzab<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The Quran is also divided into seven approximately equal parts, <a4_0><b9_0>manzil<b9_0/><a4_0/> (plural manāzil), for it to be recited in a week.
